dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Disney shutting down its Shanghai and Hong Kong theme parks really shows how serious this outbreak is getting.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Disney shutting down its Shanghai and Hong Kong theme parks really shows how serious this outbreak is getting.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: McDonalds and Disney were among the first companies to shutter businesses in China last week: Disney has shut down its Shanghai and Hong Kong theme parks, while McDonalds said that it had suspended business across five cities in the Hubei Province (the center of the outbreak).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and McDonald's closing across four cities in Hubei Province too. It's, uh, a massive operational shift for these giants.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and McDonald's closing across four cities in Hubei Province too. It's, uh, a massive operational shift for these giants.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: McDonalds and Disney were among the first companies to shutter businesses in China last week: Disney has shut down its Shanghai and Hong Kong theme parks, while McDonalds said that it had suspended business across five cities in the Hubei Province (the center of the outbreak).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Starbucks followed right after—they closed more than half of their 4,100 stores in mainland China. That's just staggering.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Starbucks followed right after-they closed more than half of their four thousand, one hundred stores in mainland China. That's just staggering.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Starbucks quickly followed suitit has now closed more than half of its 4,100 stores in mainland China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And it's not just food and entertainment. H&M closed 45 locations, and they're restricting employee travel to China as well.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's not just food and entertainment. H&M closed forty five locations, and they're restricting employee travel to China as well.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Big retailers have also shut down stores with H&M closing 45 locations and suspending business travel to and from China for its employees, according to Reuters.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and Uniqlo shuttered nearly 90 stores in Hubei. I mean, the scale of this is affecting every sector.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and Uniqlo shuttered nearly ninety stores in Hubei. I mean, the scale of this is affecting every sector.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Other companies such as IKEA and Swatch have closed stores in Wuhan, while Japanese conglomerate Fast Retailing shuttered nearly 100 of its Uniqlo stores in the Hubei province.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Even hotels like Marriott and Hilton are suspending operations in Wuhan and the greater province. Travel is just grinding to a halt.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Even hotels like Marriott and Hilton are suspending operations in Wuhan and the greater province. Travel is just grinding to a halt.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Several hotels including Marriott, Hyatt and Hilton have also suspended some operations within Wuhan and the greater Hubei province.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Speaking of travel, tech companies like Facebook and Microsoft are telling employees to avoid non-essential trips to China.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Speaking of travel, tech companies like Facebook and Microsoft are telling employees to avoid non-essential trips to China.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Tech giants like Facebook and Microsoft, for example, recently asked all of its employees to suspend non-essential travel to mainland China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and big banks too—Standard Chartered and Commonwealth Bank of Australia are on that list. It's a global ripple effect.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and big banks too-Standard Chartered and Commonwealth Bank of Australia are on that list. It's a global ripple effect.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Big banks, like Standard Chartered and the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, also said employee trips to China should be avoided.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Automakers aren't immune either. Fiat Chrysler restricted travel to Wuhan and other Chinese cities.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Automakers aren't immune either. Fiat Chrysler restricted travel to Wuhan and other Chinese cities.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Large automakers, such as Fiat Chrysler, have also restricted travel to Wuhan as well as other Chinese cities.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Though, uh, General Motors and Ford are only limiting trips to Wuhan for now, not the whole country.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Though, uh, General Motors and Ford are only limiting trips to Wuhan for now, not the whole country.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: General Motors and Ford, while restricting business trips to Wuhan, have yet to suspend travel to other parts of China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And with the government locking down over a dozen cities, around 45 million people are under travel restrictions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And with the government locking down over a dozen cities, around forty five million people are under travel restrictions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Chinese government has locked down more than a dozen cities in an attempt to quarantine the coronavirus resulting in restricted travel for some 50 million people and complicated it for many others.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That explains why so many airlines and hotels are offering free cancellations for China bookings. It's just necessary at this point.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That explains why so many airlines and hotels are offering free cancellations for China bookings. It's just necessary at this point.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A host of airlines, hotels, booking platforms and travel agencies are offering free cancellations and date changes for those who had earlier purchased trips to China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Really makes you realize how interconnected global business is—one outbreak and entire supply chains, travel plans, everything gets disrupted.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Really makes you realize how interconnected global business is-one outbreak and entire supply chains, travel plans, everything gets disrupted.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. And it's not just corporations; it's millions of individuals whose plans and livelihoods are upended.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. And it's not just corporations; it's millions of individuals whose plans and livelihoods are upended.

artist_script:
HostA: Disney shutting down its Shanghai and Hong Kong theme parks really shows how serious this outbreak is getting.
HostB: Yeah, and McDonald's closing across four cities in Hubei Province too. It's, uh, a massive operational shift for these giants.
HostA: Starbucks followed right after—they closed more than half of their 4,100 stores in mainland China. That’s just staggering.
HostB: And it’s not just food and entertainment. H&M closed 45 locations, and they’re restricting employee travel to China as well.
HostA: Right, and Uniqlo shuttered nearly 90 stores in Hubei. I mean, the scale of this is affecting every sector.
HostB: Even hotels like Marriott and Hilton are suspending operations in Wuhan and the greater province. Travel is just grinding to a halt.
HostA: Speaking of travel, tech companies like Facebook and Microsoft are telling employees to avoid non-essential trips to China.
HostB: Yeah, and big banks too—Standard Chartered and Commonwealth Bank of Australia are on that list. It’s a global ripple effect.
HostA: Automakers aren’t immune either. Fiat Chrysler restricted travel to Wuhan and other Chinese cities.
HostB: Though, uh, General Motors and Ford are only limiting trips to Wuhan for now, not the whole country.
HostA: And with the government locking down over a dozen cities, around 45 million people are under travel restrictions.
HostB: That explains why so many airlines and hotels are offering free cancellations for China bookings. It’s just necessary at this point.
HostA: Really makes you realize how interconnected global business is—one outbreak and entire supply chains, travel plans, everything gets disrupted.
HostB: Absolutely. And it’s not just corporations; it’s millions of individuals whose plans and livelihoods are upended.
